comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I know it is the next headland over, but this is surely more than a coincidence?: Tom Roberts "Sydney Harbour from Milson's Point" 1897 collection.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/collection/results.do?id...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: And 90 degrees to the left (east): Arthur Streeton "From McMahon's Point - fare one penny" 1890 cs.nga.gov.au/Detail.cfm?IRN=81092

comment.author: 13639096@N06
comment._content:
Notice the bunya pine already being planted  as a street or large garden tree. They are a Queensland tree.  Hence this one has presumably been cultivated and planted, here.  Such magnificent trees. Seem to have dropped out of favour these days.  A pity. 
(Araucaria bidwillii)

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Ho hum ... The harbour from McMahon's Point (1950) by Lloyd Rees collection.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/collection/results.do;js...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Variations on the theme ... McMahon's Point, elevated view of buildings and the harbour beyond (c.1900) [SLV: H34432, a14664] McMahon's Point, elevated view of houses and harbour beyond (c.1900) [SLV: H34435, a14667]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
A popular view - I always wondered what the three flagpoles were for - part of a signalling system?

Unfortunately the Tom Roberts painting "Sydney Harbour from Milson's Point" 1897 (see revised link above) is not this area, but Darling Harbour from Balmain (where Roberts was living at the time).  The Town Hall, St Andrews, and the old Pyrmont Bridge are clearly visible.  Who is going to tell the Art Gallery of NSW ?!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The upgraded Zoom function at the Persistent URL for all these PhM images is even more stunning.  Whack it on Full Screen +++ to see right back in time . . .
